awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Development of Next Generation Sulfur-based Batteries for Enhanced Run Time and Reduced Weight
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to help all market sectors where lithium ion (Li-ion) batteries are currently used, such as aerospace & defense, transportation, medical, oil & gas, and consumer electronics. Li-ion, the highest-performing commercially available battery technology,  currently accounts for 37% of the $23.5 billion battery market.  However, it has currently reached the maximum performance that physics and chemistry allow.  For the electric vehicle market, these performance limits would require a 1200 lb, $15,000 battery pack in an all-electric sedan, and therefore broad deployment in SUVs, pickup trucks or heavy-duty military or commercial vehicles would be commercially and economically impractical. The envisioned battery technology uses a different chemistry that potentially offers four times better storage capability than Li-ion batteries and is much lighter, leading to new economically feasible electric cars. Through unique partnerships with industry and technology commercialization, this PFI-TT project will enable testing, evaluation & refinement of the proposed technology, production scale-up and a battery prototype.

The proposed project focuses on development of Li-S batteries using a commercially-viable carbonate electrolyte, the liquid responsible for transporting Li+ ions between electrodes. The past R&D efforts for Li-S use ether electrolytes that have low boiling point (~42 degrees C) making them extremely flammable and commercially non-viable. Fundamental investigations on the role of the sulfur phase in altering the reaction mechanism have led to the development of sulfur cathodes that successfully function in carbonate electrolytes - like those used in commercial Li-ion batteries for three decades - with a stable four-fold higher capacity at the material level for 1000+ cycles.  This PFI-TT project will undertake development activities to reduce battery weight and increase sulfur loading based on success metrics provided by potential partners during preliminary customer discovery, with the objective to achieve four-fold improvement in the "device-level" specific capacity. The proposed technology will also eliminate dead weight (up to 25% of electrode weight) of binders and current collectors' passive components used in current devices and consequently eliminate slurry processing, a necessary processing step needed for current powder-based electrodes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit/Summary of Outcomes

Technologically, we focused on the development of sulfur cathodes that are compatible with carbonate electrolyte. Majority of Li-S battery developments have been conducted using ether as the electrolyte. While ether electrolytes enable high capacity Li-S batteries, they have low boiling point making them commercially inviable. Carbonate electrolytes on the other hand have boiling points greater than 200 deg C and have been used in commercial Li-ion batteries for the past three decades. However, carbonate electrolytes when used with conventional sulfur cathodes irreversibly react with intermediate polysulfides shutting down the batteries in the first cycle. For our work, we focused on design strategies employing MXenes as the host materials in Li-S batteries as well investigating sulfurized polymers as the sulfur active species. MXenes are a class of 2D materials that exhibit metallic conductivity (orders of magnitude higher than typical carbons and is of particular significance given the insulating nature of sulfur) and possess higher volume density, an important criterion to enable higher volumetric performance, particularly for portable applications such as cell phones.

The developed cathodes exhibit a stable areal capacity of ~7 mAh·cm-2 for 150 cycles at 0.1 C. For comparison, the highest areal capacity exhibited by state-of-the-art Li-ion battery devices is less than 4 mAh cm-2. To further demonstrate practical value, we developed cathodes with high sulfur loading of ~10.7 mg·cm-2 that exhibits an initial capacity of ~1000 mAh·g-1. In addition to coin cells, we also tested the cathodes in a pouch cell format. Pouch cell configuration, while rarely employed in academic literature, is an important practical testing format as severe material challenges and consequently performance challenges often remain undetected in coin cells and are a significant step towards establishing industrial-viability. Here, we demonstrate pouch cells with 60 mg sulfur loading that deliver an initial stable capacity of 900 mAh·g-1 after 5 cycles and 770 mAh·g-1 after ~200 cycles retaining 85.5% capacity. In addition to sulfur cathodes, we also developed strategies to stabilize the lithium anode in Li-S batteries. Li metal, due to its high reactivity is prone to dendrite formation resulting in short circuiting and sever safety challenges. Specifically, we created a thin polymeric interlayer placed between the lithium anode and Celgard separator. We created the interlayer with a simple blade casting technique that was performed in ambient conditions. It was then studied in Li-Li symmetric cells, showing stability through 500 cycles. Postmortem XPS of cycled cells was conducted to show evidence of LiF-based SEI layer that prevented dendrite formation and enhanced lithium metal stability.

This project led to a major sponsored research grant, which enabled us to further advance our technology, in particular it funded pouch cell making equipment in our lab as well funding and expertise to scaleup our coin cells to larger format 25 cm2 single layer pouch cells. Additionally, we completed our I-Corps training in Spring 2022 and concluded that our technology provides a strong product -market fit and that startup creation would be the most ideal path forward. PI Kalra recently co-founded a company and negotiations are underway for licensing of the patent portfolio.

 This work has resulted in 10 peer-reviewed journal articles, 9 patent applications, and 19 invited and contributed conference presentations and seminars.

 

Broader Impact

This project involved 1 undergraduate and 2 PhD students from the PI’s research group. It provided all the students involved with inter-disciplinary experience in nanomaterials and alternate energy along with opportunities to enhance their presentation and technical writing skills via several conference and group meeting presentations and paper and report writing.

This project has enabled significant exposure of PI’s student to industry partners. The key learning outcomes include 1) Understanding of specific customer technological needs in different battery application sectors and battery market pain points, 2) An ability to understand the challenges associated with technology scale-up, and 3) An ability to communicate with potential partners & investors, 4) an ability to develop battery electrodes/cells in practical industrially-relevant format. Several mechanisms were used to enable these learning outcomes –this included the I-Corp training where PI’s student led the team as the entrepreneurial lead, PI Kalra also ensured involvement of her students in communication with our network of industry partners to better understand specific customer technological needs in different battery application sectors, battery market pain points, economic factors, scale-up and commercialization issues/targets. Such exposure helped the several PhD students gain applied experiential learning experience through internship opportunities in Tesla, Arkema and Bosch.

 


Last Modified: 03/13/2025
Modified by: Vibha Kalra

Technologically, we focused on the development of sulfur cathodes that are compatible with carbonate electrolyte. Majority of Li-S battery developments have been conducted using ether as the electrolyte. While ether electrolytes enable high capacity Li-S batteries, they have low boiling point making them commercially inviable. MXenes are a class of 2D materials that exhibit metallic conductivity (orders of magnitude higher than typical carbons and is of particular significance given the insulating nature of sulfur) and possess higher volume density, an important criterion to enable higher volumetric performance, particularly for portable applications such as cell phones.

This work has resulted in 10 peer-reviewed journal articles, 9 patent applications, and 19 invited and contributed conference presentations and seminars.

This project involved 1 undergraduate and 2 PhD students from the PIs research group. It provided all the students involved with inter-disciplinary experience in nanomaterials and alternate energy along with opportunities to enhance their presentation and technical writing skills via several conference and group meeting presentations and paper and report writing.


This project has enabled significant exposure of PIs student to industry partners. The key learning outcomes include 1) Understanding of specific customer technological needs in different battery application sectors and battery market pain points, 2) An ability to understand the challenges associated with technology scale-up, and 3) An ability to communicate with potential partners & investors, 4) an ability to develop battery electrodes/cells in practical industrially-relevant format.
